Commute allows you to input your place, an amount of time you are  to commute for and a method of transport. 

Given your  destination, choose how you would like to commute and the maximum amount of time you are  to travel. Commute  show a map of potential places to live, with options to visualise layers of geographic data from ArcGIS OpenData in .geojson format.

We aggregated data from a number of sources on UK locations in order to build a database of locations, names, population sizes and distances. This allowed us to filter the number of queries beign passed to the Google Maps Distance Matrix to improve loading times (and save requests to our API key!) After getting the travel time with Google, we then plotted the map on the front end with the Esri API and  their layers and OpenData to add contextual information.
 we faced
Finding reliable data on place names in usable formats was difficult. We  a .csv file from GeoNames and an excel spreadsheet from a Government FOI request. Parsing this data and storing it in the database in an efficient way was  of the biggest .
 we're proud of

Neither of us had much prior experience in javascript, so  the Esri API was a challenge but a rewarding .
What's next

The webpage takes the 's list of interest and their location as a starting destination, along the dates and the preferred radius of travel. The output is a journey planned on the map based on their interests at the same time minimizing the prize with the SkyScanner.

It s Google Maps API to find the closest major cities within the specified radius and computes interest-related best cities to visit based on the average rating of the places on Google Maps. The cities are then passed onto SkyScanner API to search for the cheapest flights and routes. All combinations of these routes are passed onto the Traveling Salesmen Problem which computes the best path. The path and coordinates are then passed back to Esri API and displayed as a route on the map.

Small and medium-sized remote enterprises may struggle to find the best locale to set up a meeting with employees based in various different countries.

It provides the optimum location for  to congregate at minimum expense, which is of special importance for SME companies, for whom profit margins may be tight and who have no or small headquarters in few and disparate cities.

We made  of genetic search and optimization algorithms.

Defining the problem in a formal way  mathematic notation, in order to convert to a appropriate representation for the genetic algorithms.

Our solution was designed to be easily scalable, such that meetings involving larger groups would be handled with minimum additional effort.

Application of genetic algorithms. The power of API as regards the quality of data available, is an influential element to the whole solution.
 Flock

The Skyscanner API has not the ability to show indirect routes between chosen airports, which limits the effectiveness of our model. Therefore the inclusion of this feature to the API could improve our solution.

Our web service is integrated with the Google Calendar API and occasionally checks whether the  has some free time in the following month, and if they do, it tries to plan a trip for them  SkyScanner.

The original plan was to integrate both the Skyscanner API with the Esri API to come up with a hack that would allow  to identify peak travel periods to different popular destinations around the world. This would be ful to those who are avoiding the crowd, and who are looking for the cheaper destinations.

It generates a heatmap on the WebGL API, which identifies the destinations with lots of flights,  a self-written Gaussian function. It draws data from the Skyscanner API to do so.

The original idea was to  the Esri API; however, there were technical issues with parsing the data into a geolocation database object that can be rendered by the layer, so we migrated to the WebGL API, feeding it with the JSON data drawn from the Skyscanner API.

The Esri API did not offer some of the functionalities that we needed, i.e. we could not process the data to be passed into the Layer, without having access to their server (which is a paid service). There were issues with making calls to the Skyscanner API, which was only resolved in the night. We had to manually write the gaussian blur for the heat map, before mapping it to the globe. After mapping it to the globe, we had to re-plot the points on the globe, without the data stacking.

Despite the setbacks, we finally managed to complete the project, even though we had to start from scratch during the night.

Wanted to produce a website that allowed anybody to do a magic trick with very little practice.  as a professional magician, and want to change my answer after I perform from, 'sorry, I can't tell you how I did that' to 'here's something that you can learn'.

 It's an online magic trick. Read the instructions page first if you are  it. A person thinks of a card, or three  ( picks the colour,  picks the suit,  picks the value), they can change their mind as much as they want and you do not influence their decision. Whatever they say, when you click on the link a picture of their chosen card comes up. 
How I built it
 I  the code academy tutorial to learn how to initially write the basic code structure in html and css. Then I learnt how to put in the appropriate images and links onto the page, and on each letter. Didn't know what software to put the code that I had written into, so I just coded into the text file on my wordpress website on a new page. Started by coming up with a set of words that could be split into 4 instructions, to represent the four suits, with 13 characters in each instruction (minus spaces) to represent the 13 potential card values in each suit. Then coded each individual letter to correspond to each playing card (this took the bulk of the time as I had to attach an image link to every letter). I then reformatted all the information so that it was in  line as a sentence and added a title. Created a new instructions page and added a link to that. Then coded in the pictures and links, as well as centre lining the text and making it look nice. Finally I added a link from the instructions to my website (not coded during the hackathon), beca... why not right? 
 I ran into
 The biggest challenge I faced was convincing myself to start learning to code, then it was ensuring that all of the code was formatted and the website looked nice. Coming up with the word combination was difficult, as was ensuring that the link looked as much like  single hyperlink as possible. 
 that I'm proud of
 Finally got around to learning to code, and am now looking forward to  on many more exciting projects.  proud to have come up with the idea and then g on to execute it. Proud that it was all written in actual code rather than just editing the words on wordpress as I usually do with my website.
What I learned
 How to  html/css. How to create headings, change font sizes, import images, add hyperlinks, add image hyperlinks, reformat code to become  sentence,  continuously for a few hours without procrastinating. 
 Online Magic Trick - Amaze Your Friends
 Definitely going to design some more magic tricks that  can do for their friends  the platform. Hope to  them even better and far more difficult to figure out. Maybe  mix coding with some real life magic tricks.  hope to do a psychology page where  can take part in experiments (eg. implicit association tests) to see if they have implicit biases and how they compare to the rest of the population.

 FineType

 can  the headband's accelerometer to control the cursor, but the thought pattern classification subsystem does not  very well, as it is very hard to collect clean training data without a pure lab environment (e.g. no distractions, etc.).

We  Python and Ruby, as well as the M research tools. For the data analysis, we  Jupyter and scikit-learn. For the perfect UX and design, we leveraged Comic Sans MS™ and a patented marquee implementation.

It's very difficult to analyze and classify traces of EEG activity in such a limited timeframe. Moreover, collecting clean data with no distractions is nearly impossible in hackathon conditions.

We collected quite a lot of data of  performing various activities while wearing the M headband. The accelerometer-based computer control interface  s quite well!

EEG-powered human-computer interaction is possible, i.e., the signal does exist in the data. With appropriate training data collection and analysis,  could definitely build a real-time computer control system  EEG.
 We  M

This is a game with a magic theme to fit the theme of the hackathon. In this game the character has to follow game hints that lead to the player answering the ph to a friend who sends information about the location of a portal to a magical world. The way 3d graphics engines  greatly interests me so for fun, instead of  a program like unity that does the 3d for you, for this project I aimed to create a 3d game  just JavaScript, jQuery, HTML, paint images and screenshots I would take of 3d objects.
 I created 3D objects  SkectchUp then screenshotted these scenery models from lots of different angles and  JavaScript and jQuery to control when these images were displayed to create a 3d game experience for the . I   Photoshop to  the images backgrounds transparent where appropriate. The game includes some third person scenes in which the players width and height is multiplied by scalar values based on its y-coordinate to create perspective and show when the player is close or far away. This scene  includes some quick first person moments which occur when an object of great importance to the games story appears and the  is able to view this item in first person. This was d to  sure the  sees this object up close and notices it. As the player opens the portal the world distorts a bit to empathise the magical powers of the portal. Magic dust  appears above the flashing portal. Once the portal is opened the magical world is all in first person. The player is transported to a magical castle which they can freely walk up and down  corridor of. The corridor appears clear at first but as soon as the player starts to walk an enchanted floating hat appears. 
When making the game I came across many .  of these was that the number of screenshots needed to  a smooth running 3D game was too large. I had to compromise and limit the number of images  to a reasonable number. I  struggled with problems ca by code written for different stages of the game affecting thing in a part of the game they were not intended for. The solution to this was to give each stage of the game a boolean variable that tracks if it should have started running yet or not. This helped me keep track of which stage of the game the  was in and what code should and shouldn’t run for this stage of the game. 
The main thing I leant was how to  the 3d for the first person scene in the game (in the castle scene). In the future, to expand on the game I could  the game longer so that you can explore more of the castle.

That's why Garrelt hitchhikers!
Garrelt misses security, comfort and fun when traveling to his admired destination.

We had to advance the app's usability to  it comfortable for both participants  the app throughout a longer route. Additionally the driver shouldn't be distracted while driving.  that I'm proud of
We're proud of the simplicity of our API and the fact of  speech massages as a function to  both participant into contact.
What I learned
We learned a lot about the  with gps targeted development and the small  when  in Android Studio.
 Hitchhacking
We  need to advance our algorithm for finding  with matching directions, to  it more functional in urban areas.
We would like to implement speech recoginition for having less interaction with the app through the driver.
Our matching algorithm for common interest has some more room for improvement and should be implemented as a self learning .

The original plan was to integrate both the Skyscanner API with the Esri API to come up with a hack that would allow  to identify peak travel periods to different popular destinations around the world. This would be ful to those who are avoiding the crowd, and who are looking for the cheaper destinations.

It generates a heatmap on the WebGL API, which identifies the destinations with lots of flights,  a self-written Gaussian function. It draws data from the Skyscanner API to do so.

The original idea was to  the Esri API; however, there were technical issues with parsing the data into a geolocation database object that can be rendered by the layer, so we migrated to the WebGL API, feeding it with the JSON data drawn from the Skyscanner API.

The Esri API did not offer some of the functionalities that we needed, i.e. we could not process the data to be passed into the Layer, without having access to their server (which is a paid service). There were issues with making calls to the Skyscanner API, which was only resolved in the night. We had to manually write the gaussian blur for the heat map, before mapping it to the globe. After mapping it to the globe, we had to re-plot the points on the globe, without the data stacking.

Despite the setbacks, we finally managed to complete the project, even though we had to start from scratch during the night.

The idea arose at the Great Uni Hackathon 2016. The challenge announced by Noma was to create a solution to the following problem:

How do we help a potential occupier understand size and available space options in a building without physically 
taking them there?

We began with the end  in mind. Who would actually be  this product?
The operator is going to be the agencies trying to let the spaces in the buildings. The  would be any interested in occupying the building. We do not  assumptions about the technical abilities of either of these s. Hence we needed to devise something which was intuitive to , but not too difficult to set up. Virtual reality is  option, as it allows the potential occupier to 'walk' around the office, and get a real feel for the size.
We couldn't  an Oculus Rift. Here's why:

It requires a computer with exceptional graphics ability
It requires some with technical knowledge to set up
It is relatively expensive
The wires can be very cumbersome

We decided to go instead with the Google Cardboard:

It s a ph. Most  in business have a ph capable of creating VR scenes.
The setup is minimal. You launch an app and the experience is setup
Google Cardboard costs £5 -- A more comfortable Homido costs £50.


There are two parts to the system, the website, and the mobile application.
The Website
The Website is for  by the operator - the building space retailer. It provides a very simple interface which allows the  to draw out the scene, and then see a very basic visualisation of how the scene might look in three dimensions. It provides options for visualising the scene, clearing any mistakes, and sending the data over to the mobile application.
The Application
The mobile application was built for Android, and allowed the display to be configured for Virtual Reality. With simplicity in mind, the  only needs to launch the app, request the data from the website with a simple click, then put the ph in the headset to have a look around.

The Website
The website was developed with the standard suite of web languages: HTML, CSS and JavaScript. For the CSS, we  Bootstrap to ensure that there was a consistent style guide, and to  the webpage pseudo-responsive. For the 3D modelling and display, we  three.js to provide a JavaScript wrapper for OpenGL. We   jQuery to send AJAX requests to build the API.
We took the following approach to building the website:

Design and create the layout
Have the 3D visualisation  for a fake input matrix
Create a grid matrix to feed into the visualisation
Create the API which can then be read by the mobile application

The Application
The application was build with Unity, which provides tools to create Virtual Reality scenes. The application connected to the API and downloaded a matrix representing the geometry of the space. It then goes through the matrix and procedurally generates the space. The  is then able to move around the scene by  the ph's gyrometer, and by performing different actions.

Wireless amp systems are really cool and convenient, but they're  crazy expensive. I thought I'd really like  but there was no way I could afford a professional , so what other option did I have but to  my own?! After recently seeing a talk about the Web Audio API at a conference, I really wanted to try it out, so I thought I would!

 an iRig (or some other device/cable) you plug your guitar into your ph and open up the 'play' page of amp in a browser. Then open the 'listen' page on another device and you'll be able to hear the amplified guitar playing - no wires between the two!
How I built it
It s the Web Audio API to get the input from the guitar, which effectively acts like a microph when plugged into the ph. It then s Socket.io-p2p to stream the audio via WebRTC to the 'listen' page. The Node.js server is there only to serve the static pages and to facilitate the handshaking of the p2p WebRTC connection between the 'play' and 'listen' pages.
 I ran into
The Web Audio API is still under active development (read: everybody is still arguing about how it should ), and so is WebRTC. Having previously  Socket.io many times, I thought it would be a good idea to  their p2p module to stream the audio. In the end it ed out okay, but the documentation was a bit rubbish.
Another major issue is the latency. When running the 'play' and 'listen' clients on the same machine, the latency is manageable, but over the net it's too much to be able to play guitar. This does somewhat invalidate this entire hack, but please ignore that fact.
 that I'm proud of
I managed to get Socket.io-p2p , something that as far as I can  out, not that many  have d. It ended up being a great wrapper for WebRTC, but the documentation really needs . I've started on making an example of how to do media streaming over it, which I plan to submit a pull request for as this is something totally undocumented as of right now.
What I learned
WebRTC is pretty cool, and definitely something to look out for in the future. Same goes for the Web Audio API. Good documentation is  crazy important (but definitely already knew this).
 amp
I'd really like to look into adding some traditional-style guitar effects (distortion, etc). Reducing the latency is probably top of the list for now though. Not entirely sure how I can do that!

We gathered the  for the NOMA challenge as we found the most interesting and challenging out of the few that were up for grabs. Our team thought that the task of  with virtual reality, modelling and innovation  was the most suitable so we built upon it.

The hack itself is basically set to innovate the way  buy real estate: instead of going to every single location by foot or car, the customer would have the ability to meet with an agent or just view the estate from home with any VR headset. But our project does not just stop there - the main goal is to not only be able to view the rooms, but to actually customize them yourself! You could add any furniture you desire just to have a better feel on how a specific property tailors to your needs! In addition to that, the engine would  in such a way that you only need to implement the type of ho you need (office, flat, etc.), the amount of occupants and the system  automatically generate a room with certain types of furniture in it in a specific formation. The last thing to be implemented would be a machine learning algorithm that actually learns from customers needs and s better assumptions as to what type of ho to offer!

The project was build by  a simple piece of hardware and a few pieces of software, that being the the famous Samsung VR gear, 3D modeling software BLENDER and last but certainly not least, the Unreal Engine for the actual mapping of items and surroundings. We decided to  the Unreal engine as it has a really friendly  interface called "blueprint" that actually helps minimize the amount of low level code and move building blocks of the program into a more high level environment.

During our development path we have encountered quite a few hurdles: the largest of them being the massive struggle with the Oculus rift. The main issue with the rift was that we spent an actual 9 hours trying to get it to  on our laptops. We went to the extent of trying a campus computer to no avail. This automatically led to a loss of precious time, but we managed to get back from it and come back with a bang! The setback did not terminate our drive and we came out with a finished alpha version of the app that we are very proud to present!

We manage to deal with the setback from the OCULUS, dealt with numerous errors from Unreal engine, and finally came out with a  product!

We have learned a great lesson in team as well as actual software and hardware skills that helped us implement our project!
 VReal Estate
Who knows, the app might  day reach an actual beta version!

Travis CI Status

Description
Fragile/Swarming Geese Simulator, is a Python program that "simulates" the
behaviour of geese (a common theme around Birmingham). The main idea was to
create the activity history of groups and individual geese and then plot their
actions on a map ( Google Maps API). The history is stored  the crate.io
database.
How to run the program.
source/geesemanager.py

This  start a custom "shell" that allows you to call some of the main
functions of the program. You can   RAW Python if you wish.
Inside the "shell" you can run:
jimmy = createGoose()

This  start a "wizzard" to help you define
Jimmy, you can either  random data or custom
data.
jimmy = createGoose()
 random data? (y/n)
---> y
>_

Now we have a random goose in 'jimmy'.
print jimmy
89e129f6
>_

Printing 'jimmy' like that  return the hashid.
If we were to choose custom data for 'jimmy', the
setup would look like this:
>_ jimmy = createGoose()
 random data? (y/n)
---> n
name ---> Jimmy
age (d) ---> 600
span (d) ---> 600
health ---> 200
hunger ---> 300
X: 90
Y: 80
gender ---> 2
range ---> 55
>_

Creating a clan.
>_ someclan = createClan(50,0,2)
# 50 is the number of geese.
# 0 is the X coordinate.
# 2 is the Y coordinate.

Simulating a clan.
>_ start(someclan)
# After this you are prompted to give a date.
# Then hell breaks loose!!!
# Some geese die, some are born, overall they win!

More
For more information on what the program can do, look at the functions defined inside source/geesemanager.py

crate.io
The program tries to connect to a crate.io database, so  sure you have  running
crate/crate # Linux/Mac

and when asked provide the ip and port:
# Should  on most machines!
ip: localhost
port: 4200

After this, Python connects to the database and stores data about the geese! AMAZING!

Initially we started big: Majestic API, huge crate.io database on amazon server and so on... And well, we failed. But instead of just giving up, we decided to have some fun and create something we would enjoy  on. And that's pretty much the origin of Bomber Goose.

It's pretty much a casual game of bomberman. But this time it bombers as geese, Galaxy Note 7 as the bomb, MLH symbol as power up and AstonHack hackingspace as area. For control, just enter the website address on your mobile ph and it  turn it into controller and add you as another player.

We are running Amazon server for the main game, with .tech domain to connect to it. Entering bombergoose.tech/player.html on your mobile ph  add you to the game and display mobile controller. s on both Android and iOS. The area of the game is made from pictures of AstonHack hacking space.

Spending countless hours browsing geese pics on internet.

Well, we didn't really build linux kernel from scratch. Or create facebook in machine code. But we had fun. We met cool . We enjoyed every minute of AstonHack and that's what we are most proud of. 

That hackathon isn't just an event to improve your skills,  projects that  shine on your CV or win . It's mainly about just having fun with other . It doesn't matter how advanced your project  be, it's about how much you enjoy doing it.

GitHub's visualizations of repositories are pretty cool. Since commits are laid out in time it made sense to  it to sequence sound.

It takes a GitHub repository (name/reponame) and plays a drum track based on the commit history of the master branch. When the commits are more frequent it speeds up and vice-versa.
How I built it
I grab data from GitHub's repository API, rescale the timing to  it somewhat drum-like and  the WebAudio API to sequence drum samples.
 I ran into
 major problem is that most repositories follow the pattern of big spikes of activity and loads of idle time. That s the tracks very boring to listen to. I transformed the timings so that it never speeds up or slows down too much.
 that I'm proud of
Wrangling the timing in WebAudio is something completely new to me, so I'm happy to have learned more about it. Finding the right parameters for solution to the above problem was  pretty great!
What I learned
Dealing with browser-based audio and the awesome GitHub API.
 DrumHub
I'm taking it on tour.

 I ran into

Do you want to find out who your true friends are? Who likes you in secret? Who really hates you? You're in luck, and with just a simple game of Thrisbee™ you can now find out!

Pass it round, and see the stats on the cool display and enjoy your metrics!
It'll show you plenty of ful information such as who's passing the Thrisbee™ to whom, who's the most popular, the least, how fair the game is and how much fun you're having!

The main micro:bit is mounted on the underside of the Thrisbee™. Each person playing the game then has a micro:bit on their person broadcasting who they are over Bluetooth, and the Thrisbee™ s the RSSI values of the player's bits broadcasts to determine who's holding it.
The Thrisbee™ then relays the player information and its accelerometer values to a gateway bit connected to a laptop, which gets the data over serial, into matlab which plots graphs and key performance indicators in real time.

The Bluetooth link had some issues of reliability when sending more data over the link, and not all data was received and recovered properly. 
We  ed on some mechanics calculations to calculate throw speed, impact, rotations speed and distance thrown, getting promising results but needing more time to implement them fully.

We made the Thrisbee™ communicate both with the player's bits and with the gateway bit simultaneously, enabling it to relay which player is holding or throwing it to the computer.
It's  great fun and illuminating in terms of your social standing..

We learned a lot about  Bluetooth to communicate between these devices, as well as getting familiar with the mbed platform and microcontroller to microcontroller communication.
We  learned about the limitations of accelerometers and magnetometers, such as limited sampling rates and the importance of signal processing.
 Internet of Thrisbee™
The next steps are  's smartphs instead of micro:bits for the detection of who's holding it, and making an app that gets the data over Bluetooth from the Thrisbee™, processes it and shows all the graphs and metrics.
Add a rechargeable battery, embed the microcontroller in an injection molded custom Thrisbee™, pair it with an induction charger and a smartph app, and sell it to ultimate frisbee teams and any who likes fun!

When cycling to the ARM 2016 hackathon, we experienced some of the commons problem of cycling in a group. Issuing directions is not always easy, and keeping up with the leader can be even harder - if some falls behind, it becomes difficult to attract the group's attention to get them to wait.

We saw a live plot of the Microbit accelerometer data on an app and were intrigued by the way the sensor readings reacted to our movement. An idea for a game started to appear......
Micro-2048 is a gesture driven 2048 game. The player swipes a Microbit across the air to move the tiles on the screen. It s radio connection, which means that the player can play it without sitting in front of a computer.
We  two Microbits,  is connected to the computer via serial. This then talks to a Node.js server, which relays the sensor information to a browser based javascript game. The other Microbit acts as a game controller, it publishes the gestures it detects through the radio. Together they  a  gesture driven game.
We initially had another idea that involved a lot of electronics. Unfortunately, we lacked the compnts and the experience needed to execute that idea, so we had to switch ideas with only 12 hours left to spare. However, we did manage to successfully pivot and re most of our code for a completely different application
A few of our teammates no little experience with python, but they managed to learn rapidly during the course of the Hackathon and gained a fundamental knowledge by the end of it. 
We have learnt is that it is much more efficient to start with something with basic functionality and then iterate to  it better, rather than aiming too high from the beginning. , it's very important to be flexible and  directional changes when necessary. The most important of all is that we should enjoy the process, and not chase the destination.
This project act as a proof of concept that Microbits can bring a completely new experience to gaming. In the future, more games may be powered by the Microbit with more complex gesture drove interfaces.

For elderly, ill or disabled family and friends, the risk of falling is a serious concern. 
In fact, research carried out by the Department of Surgery at the University of Rochester medical centre found that the elderly over the age 70 are three times more likely to be fatally injured. In many cases, for elderly adults who are frail and have pre-existing medical conditions, what seems like a minor fall can lead to a broken hip or bs. In the scenario that these individuals are al or cannot easily gain access to some - this can lead to far reaching and very serious consequences. 

When a  falls, trips or sustains any significant impact, an emergency call is established with a list of guardians informing them of the 's emergency. 

The necklace consists of a BBC Microbit, which s its accelerometer to measure significant impact. When the acceleration exceeds a threshold, the Microbit sends an emergency message via Bluetooth LE to a Raspberry-Pi. The Raspberry-Pi s an HTTP GET request to our Node.js server, which in turn establishes a call with the guardian of the   the Twilio Call API. 


the Twilio API was not straight forward 
the microbit is designed for children, and has thus a built-in authentication process, which you're required to do before sending any data. 
bluetooth Low Energy disconnects regularly and at a lower range than expected. 



we built an end-to-end system, which is precisely what we wanted to do from the offset. 
our project encompasses many different technologies, from hardware programming with C++ and Python to setting up a server in Node.js and  an external API service. 



we've learnt to program the microbit in C++, and the Raspberry-Pi in Python and Bluetooth Programming in general.

Hand drawn touch sensors



Sensor consists of a grid of graphite (pencil drawn) squares.
Touching a square increases its capacitance; this is detected by measuring (with an Arduino nano) the time taken to charge the capacitor.
Finger location is  to control tempo and pitch of tune being played by a micro bit
Micro bit LEDs visualise the tune being played, and can display the detected location of a finger on the touch pad.

You've seen the Theremin? We are the next that.

By tilting and turning a microbit, a harmonised melody is created on 3 other microbits.

With 1 microbit acting as the net master and 3 other as its slaves, we broadcast the direction and tilt to the slave microbits. The slaves calculate the octave and specific note of the scale from this data and produces an appropriate pitch on a Grove Buzzer. We have modified the code on each of the microbits so that it harmonises the notes produced.

We live in the world where  has always stay in touch. Our ability to quickly read emails or just access internet is often essential in our . And yet still, over 60% of world population doesn't have access to internet. Even we often find ourselves in a position where we either run out of mobile data, don't have any credits on our account or there is no internet connection in our area. We decided to fix this problem with Netless.

Netless is basically an offline web browser, that allows you to view websites even if you don't have access to internet. All you need is ability to send SMS from your ph and in return you can view any website you want in text version.

We built an Android app, which looks similar to a traditional web browser. When you type the desired website into address bar, our app  send it as SMS to Twilio service. Our Amazon based server  then collect the HTML code of typed website, compress it and send the code back to 's ph (again, via SMS). 

It turned out that the HTML code of websites is usually far too big to fit in text messages. Typical Wikipedia pages contains hundreds of thousands of characters, while typical SMS can contain up to 160 characters. We dealt with it by heavily compressing the HTML file and removing unnecessary parts from it.
 Netless
Improving the compression of html file is our highest priority. It would decrease number of SMS sent for website to load, and therefore, improve app performance significantly. Other features we wish to implement:
-saving websites offline
-Google/Wikipedia search
-Wolphram Alpha replies
-facebook/gmail notifications
-turn on SMS notifications automatically after ph loses internet connection

Monzo is a bank based entirely on a smartph app. However, we noticed that if your went abroad you may not be able to view notifications for transactions or your balance if you did not have data roaming which can be quite expensive. Luckily SMS is cheap and so this project allows a  to request that transaction information is sent to them via SMS  the Twilio API and Monzo API. We found that this is actually a requested feature on the Monzo forum.: community.monzo.com/t/abroad-sms-notifications/4854
The AWS server runs the code to authenticate s with Monzo's OAuth as well as handling webhooks from Monzo and Twilio. At this time it is not possible to authenticate other s due to Monzo limitations. s  get transaction reports near instantly pushed to them and they can send messages to our bot to ask questions about their account such as their balance and daily spend. 
We aim to integrate IBM Watson further into the project to allow natural conversations with the system.

ShareLive was inspired by an article published in the "Frontiers in Psychology" journal by researchers at the University of Oxford about how sharing the experience of listening to music can increase social bonding.

ShareLive allows s to share music live (there's up to 5 seconds of latency) with friends over the internet.
How I built it
Most of the code is written in JavaScript. There's a very simple (18 lines of code) back end written in PHP. The front end is stylised  bootstrap.
 I ran into
YouTube doesn't allow all videos to be embedded, due to the various different licensing arrangements they have - so I had to  sure my web app took this into account and didn't offer s videos which were unplayable. I designed a bespoke events protocol  pusher to synchronise clients "peer to peer" - all the back end does is authorise connections (all connections are automatically authorised, however pusher requires connections to be authorised  a back end before they can broadcast data).
Unfortunately my web app doesn't yet  on mobile due to issues with automatically playing / pa videos (see the YouTube documentation for more information). I hope that this issue can be overcome in the near future.
 that I'm proud of
It all s fairly smoothly. The  interface is quite friendly, and is looks reasonably nice. This was my first "major" (4+ hours of coding time) project  JavaScript - it's a good way to write cross-platform applications.
What I learned
I learned how to write a substantial application  JavaScript, and how to  Pusher without having a central backend to keep track of state. I think this is really ful - by  client-side programming and peer-to-peer communication costs are kept to a minimum and applications are generally scalable by nature.
 ShareLive
There are a few items on the to do list. I'd really like to integrate with Spotify instead of YouTube, as Spotify offers greater music choice and higher sound quality. Access to their APIs is by application / invitation only, so hopefully this proof-of-concept can show that this is a good idea.

Laravel is a web application frame with expressive, elegant syntax. We believe development must be an enjoyable, creative experience to be truly fulfilling. Laravel attempts to take the pain out of development by easing common tasks  in the majority of web projects, such as authentication, routing, sessions, queueing, and caching.
Laravel is accessible, yet powerful, providing powerful tools needed for large, robust applications. A superb inversion of control container, expressive migration system, and tightly integrated unit testing support give you the tools you need to build any application with which you are tasked.
Official Documentation
Documentation for the frame can be found on the Laravel website.
Contributing
Thank you for considering contributing to the Laravel frame! The contribution guide can be found in the Laravel documentation.
Security Vulnerabilities
If you discover a security vulnerability within Laravel, please send an e-mail to Taylor Otwell at taylor@laravel.com. All security vulnerabilities  be promptly addressed.
License
The Laravel frame is open-sourced software licensed under the MIT license

project_description:
After the success of the original AchimQuest at HackTheMidlands, we were eager to expand the Achim universe. After brainstorming several ideas we eventually settled on a Bomberman-style game featuring our favourite maths lecturer.

Much like Bomberman, in the game you control  of several Achims around an arena, dropping bombs (in the shape of Martin Escardo) to destroy enemies and walls. The game is controlled by the players' phs (by accessing a control pad on a server) while the game arena is displayed on the main screen.

The main game is built  node.js, and the server-ph communication is handled  socket.io (unfortunately Pusher proved inadequate for our purpose).

We initially tried to  Pusher to handle our server-ph communication, however this proved impossible for real-time events that we were aiming for. Another main problem was communicating the location of walls from the server to the main map.

We are proud of the ability to  phs as controllers - this is kind of cool.

This was the first time George had  JavaScript, so this was a good opportunity to develop his skills.
What's next
If we were to continue we could develop the multiplayer aspect further.

Lookup pizzas from Pizza Hut and Dominos based on your postcode to find you the best prices

The python server scrapes the two websites to obtain data on the pizzas available from your local store,  Python's requests to keep track of the cookies from the websites. A JSON object is returned containing the pizzas, which can be filtered, sorted and searched from the website. 
Ideally, I would have included deals available too, but Domino's website required me to restart my server after every request to their deals details which made it more complex to do, and Pizza Hut  images to show details, which would have required computer vision to solve this, and after spending over 14 hours on the web scraping, I had little time to do this.

As the aging population of the UK turns into an inverted period, Dementia becomes more and more of a pressing issue. The time consuming nature of Dementia Questionnaires in a time where General Practice Surgeries are constrained with time and resources, promotes need for more efficient way of screening.

Removes the need for human interaction to do 20-30 minute questionnaire, saving time for the GP, translated to improved efficiency in services. Questionnaire  be d before GP appointment for annual medication review, Results  be available to be discussed during the GP appointment. It  demonstrate the likely hood/ risk of having dementia,  promoting GP to conduct detailed clinical examination to confirm diagnosis.

For HackSheffield 2.0, we designed a video game to fit within what we felt was realistic ambitions.  We drew artistic  from games such as "Gods  Be Watching" and "The Secret of Monkey Island" - and loosely based our primary game mechanic on... "Papers, Please" and... maybe "Guess Who"? With hindsight, the game turned out rather similar to Sheffield's Assassin's Guild society - and as two of our developers are indeed members, this is PROBABLY not coincidence. Call it subconscious game design, or whatever floats your boat.
"The Dossier" was a game designed to combine the talents of our four developers. We decided on a video game, as this is where the majority of our cumulative experience lies - video game development. Rather than limiting us, this let us draw from a dauntingly vast pool of disciplines that making a decent game requires. Art, programming, web development, and creative writing - we split our team of four rather neatly into these four different categories.


The Dossier features intrigue, espionage, and pirates. Put simply, there's a load of characters in a room -  of whom is your "target". Equipped with a rather vague "briefing file", along with each character's dialogue and appearances, you are tasked with identifying your target correctly.
The quicker you  a correct identification, the more points you score - and after five rounds of investigation, your score is uploaded to an online leaderboard. We've  got functionality to post your score to twitter, beca social media.

Oh, and did we mention that we composed and arranged an entire soundtrack for The Dossier? (A 15 second chip-tune loop, don't get excited.)

The game itself was developed in the Game r engine,  GML (Game r Language), whilst the assets were hand drawn in a image editor called "Krita". Tying everything together were various Google Drive folders and documents, which  found themselves spontaneously filled with tonnes and tonnes of god-awful character dialogue - as if from thin air...

Last but by no means least, we  HTML, CSS, and PHP to get the online leaderboard up and running.

Coding wise, matching up the sprite animations with the character movement, alongside varying the game with each play (random characters chosen from a pool of possibilities), proved to be something of a timesink.
Regarding asset creation, the large load for a project of this nature made it difficult to produce content fast enough. We were able to overcome this through re- many of our assets - modifying the originals to  them unique.
Finding a web hosting service proved tricky, to say the least. This, combined with a mid-hackathon fresh OS install, set the leaderboard development a little behind other aspects of the game.


All of us on the team, having never ed together before, were able to successfully meet the load of the game we designed from the beginning. It was stressful at times, and plain tedious at others, but we unanimously pulled through and were to deliver a game that lived up to our expectations.


The most significant thing we learned was that: allocating roles is effective. The four of us ed on very different, equally important aspects of the project, but maintained communication throughout. In this way, we made progress on our individual tasks, whilst helping each other and making design decisions as a group.

 The Dossier
Whilst we don't intend to continue developing The Dossier, we certainly learned a lot from its development, and find it likely that we'll collaborate again on a future project.

We're not quite sure ourselves. Our initial idea was to build a world thanks to leap motion, shaping it like clay with our own hands. Instead we ended with a political satire. We wanted to  natural language processing for our project and to  a good project we needed a wealth of data which we collect from Twitter. Once we'd gathered some interesting statistics we wanted to  something pretty!

A Twitter  name is given by the  and recent posts from that  are  to create a graph of how positive their messages are.

When the Twitter name is submitted a socket is opened.  We  the Twitter API to collect recent posts from that  which are then sent of to Google natural language processing API. The result from this is two metrics called polarity (how positive the message contents is) and magnitude (how strong the language  is) as well as a list of mentions of other Twitter s. This information is then sent via a socket connection back to the  where WebGL is  to graph the results  WebGL (via the ThreeJS library).

The nature of the Twitter and Google APIs made it very difficult to pass data between the two and then reunite the results with the original Tweets. Half of the team had never  JS before and n of us had any experience with Web/OpenGL which was made worse by the lack of documentation for some areas of ThreeJS.

Data s it reliably from Twitter -> Google ->  and does so relatively quickly. Client side drawing of interactive graph looks great! Despite being build quickly the whole project is built in such a way that we could fairly quickly implement other features (see What's next...).

WebGL, Javascript, lots about asynchronous connections and more ninja git shell skills!
 The Twitter Sphere
If the socket connections was held open after the initial data is sent then the 's graph could be updated with new posts in (near) real time. We could  allow for the graph to expand beyond  step away from the original  name entered. More animations for the graph  the huge amount of data available to drive pretty (but  insightful) animations.

Ever wondered what to do on a boring weeknight? Well fear not, as Alexa is here to challenge you to an epic rhyme off!

This project allows you to play a rhyming game with Alexa, going back and forth until some gives in (hint: that's gonna be you). Just start the game and give Alexa a word to , and she'll handle the rest. Just  sure you've brushed up on your rhymes! Who ever can't think of a rhyme fast enough, or repeats themselves first  be the loser.
How it was built
We build this whole project  node.js and the Amazon Alexa Skills SDK, while  making  of an online rhyming dictionary API.

It was a challenge to get Alexa setup and running, and it was even trickier to integrate the functions for the rhyming API into that.

We created our first skill for Alexa, which was a very rewarding challenge, and we  managed to have fun while doing it!

Practice s perfect--this event stimulates us to practice coding skills. Although, we are not experts in coding, we like coding and want to learn more in the future. The result does not matter, the process matters much more.

The Trainline app introduced a new feature a while ago where it asks you whether there are any free seats on the train that you're on. I thought it would be an interesting idea to do something similar for ticket barriers at stations.

It's a Telegram (similar to WhatsApp) bot which checks whether ticket barriers are open at stations based on  data. Go and chat to it to find out the commands.
How I built it
Started out wanting it to be a Messenger bot, but ended up  Telegram instead. It's written in Node.js and stores all its data in Redis. I found the data for all the station codes online - somebody managed to get access to the National Rail API and just dumped all the data.
 I ran into
Messenger bots are required to be approved. There's no way they'd approve this! So I switched to Telegram.
 that I'm proud of
I keep learning new cool things about Redis! Most  only  it as a cache of some sort, but I'm loving it as my primary data store. I quite enjoy  around its limitations.
What I learned
Messenger platform, for all the hype surrounding it, is actually a bit rubbish.
 Gatesopen
I'd really like to incorporate some kind of ML to learn which stations usually have their barriers open at a specific time of day. I think it would  be cool to  in some natural language processing so that conversations with the bot become a bit more human.

Our  for this project was to be able to represent the data available to us visually so it was easier for s to see and understand, and add interactivity for the  when analysing the data.

The project visualises the Millennium Point data  a 3d space created in Unity. The  has the ability to move between the three main floors of the millennium point building to see the number of   each entrance on each floor. The number of  entering is visualised through a circle that expands when more  enter through that entrance. The program  displays if the day or week is a school holiday, an event or during BCU term time. Averages of the  entering is  shown by Day and by week. 

First we formatted the given data so that it could be loaded into unity. Next we sourced the floor plans for the building to locate the entrances for  in the product. We then created the UI plan and the 3D world to represent the data we were given.  

 only run on 64 Bit windows, can be recompiled for any OS if desired*


The main  we encountered were parsing the original data given for the challenge beca the data was not always in a consistent format which could be passed easily for  in the unity engine. Labelling the entrances  proved a challenge as some were not clear to see and were not labelled on the floor plan. Creating a GUI similar to the design of Millennium Point  proved a challenge but we created  by comparing the GUI to documents and the Millennium point website.

Through the project we were able to create a project that was aesthetically pleasing for the general public but  could be  to display information throughout the year for the different entrances to the building. We are  proud of  game engine technology to visual data to large audiences with data analysing capabilities.

We learnt time management skill, delegation of responsibility to maximise the resources available. We  learnt more about  Unity3D and programming in C#.
 HTM Millennium Point Data Challenge
To improve the project for future  we would let it accept more general data files, to accept custom data which we could not do due to the time constraints of the project. We would  implement more advanced data analysis to provide details of trends over time.

There is nothing more unique than having a poem created from the interpretation of an image

It takes an image, URL or from the computer, runs it through Clarifai's API to generate a list of tags associated with that picture, then it grabs a multitude of lines of poems from a database, sees which combination is the best through IBM Watson, and chooses the best  according to an emotional parameter.

We divided the  into making sure we can grab the list of tags from an arbitrary image, while the other person was taking care of the poem generation from dummy data. When things got connected, we expanded and got to polish everything up, and spent the rest of the time optimising the poem generation, through choosing the best lines of poems and having them judged by IBM Watson's T Analyser.
 I ran into
Python proved to be challenging for us since we weren't experienced enough in it. We sometimes spent more time doing trivial stuff that should be accomplished immediately in a comfortable language. Nevertheless, practice s perfect, and we never got impeded enough that moving forward wasn't an option anymore.  
 that we are proud of
We successfully glued together a remarkable number of APIs and functions all in a python script designed to synthesize awe from analytical data. Parsing JSON proved to be easier than expected, APIs credentials and authentication went surprisingly well. We managed to simulate meaningful emotion in the form of a poem from a picture of basically anything.
What I learned
Knowing your tools goes a long way, as well as having a really organised  environment that can support even the most difficult research sessions.
 Poem from your picture

At the start, we were considering a treasure hunting game, where there would be  organiser who would select different places (eg landmarks) around a city. We have been considering QR codes to  with this project, so each of the 'players' could scan the codes after they had found  of the places marked by the organiser. However, after some brainstorming, we have decided to allow any of the s to be able to submit a location to find. This way, the first player to find that location would get points. We decided to scrap the idea of QR codes, as these would be too much of a hassle to print out for every , especially if only  player would be able to  the code afterwards. Instead, a player who finds  of the locations marked has to take a picture of it, and wait for the approval of the original poster of the location. If it is approved, the  is rewarded with 10 points. As the icon of the game if a camera with an arrow through it, we decided to call the points "arrows".
We have been considering several platforms for the game, but in the end we chose to  the application  XCode in the language Swift, as we had a team member with a lot of prior experience. We  distributed jobs for the rest of us, with  of us sketching and making the design, and  team member researching the back-end database.
We ran into several . First of all, finding a good solution for the back-end was difficult without a good understanding of XCode and Swift. In the end, we decided to  a service called Quickblox, with allowed us to create a database and  manage the data in the application. Another challenge we ran into was the time limit, as even though we tried our best to keep , we had to scrap some features that we had been considering originally, such as having locations displayed on a map, which would have been a nice extra feature, however it was unfeasible given the time we had.
Each of us have learned new skills, as we have all been  with tasks we had never d before.  understanding the importance of communication was important, and I strongly believe we each became closer to each other as friends.
If we were to continue developing this application in the future, we would add other features such as preventing s from finding the chosen locations of the same player more than once or twice, to ensure cheating would be difficult. , we would implement a map feature, to  locations easier to find around the city, by giving a radius on the map to show hints about where the locations are.
Overall, we each enjoyed this experience, and definitely learnt new skills, and just had fun  together generally.

We were inspired by Majestic, who provided us with their great API.

The application interprets Twitter s' opinions on different topics of your choice. It searches for tweets related to your keyword, selects the most popular s  the Majestic API and analyses them  Google's Natural Language Processing API. We are showing the general opinion of the  and the most frequently  adjectives when talking about the respective topic. 
It can  analyse a 's Twitter activity, showing information about patterns in his tweets and his overall attitude when posting, as well as the number of links pointing to his profile.

We built the back end API in Python and Node.js, which is called on the client side  html, css and angularjs. We  external APIs like Twitter's REST, Google's Natural Language Processing and Majestic API.

Putting all these technologies together and making sure they cooperate effectively is a difficult task.

We are proud of managing to interpret all this information and to visualise it in a nice way.

We got an insight into data analysis and natural language processing.
 AskTwitter
We plan on finding new ways of  Google's and Majestic's data and refining the application.

Having found nothing to do at Hack the Midlands, I decided to sit down and brush up on my Java knowhow. Looking at tutorials for making games in Java, I stumbled across a tutorial to  a shooter. This was the humble beginnings of AchimQuest, but now it has evolved into something far beyond the scope of that tutorial.

AchimQuest is based on classic bullet hell shooters, where  must dodge enemies and their attacks while trying to survive. This version of AchimQuest features four levels plus  boss level (featuring a surprise boss!), in addition to the ability to change characters whenever you want.
How I built it
As mentid earlier, AchimQuest initially started as a Java tutorial online. However when I received positive feedback from my peers, I decided to continue with AchimQuest and  it into a fully fledged game. I  my knowledge of Java graphics (awt and swing) to create a proper GUI and made more  of keyboard presses to increase functionality.
 I ran into
Java graphics are extremely fiddly, as I found out. Most of the bugs I encountered were usually due to something not being painted or made visible at the right time. 
 that I'm proud of
I am most proud of the boss fight, which was coded much more blindly (the boss moves differently to the other enemies and is the only  who can fight back, as well as the only  who can withstand a large amount of hits, and change his movement appropriately when hurt).
What I learned
I learned some basic game development techniques which  surely come in ful later on in my career. I  dabbled in audio and image manipulation within Java.
 AchimQuest
If I continue to  on AchimQuest I could perhaps  on special attacks, multiplayer (co-op) and advanced attack patterns.

This project is inspired by the Wikipedia Game, in which you have to get from  Wikipedia article to another  by just clicking on links in the articles.

The idea is very similar to that of the Wikipedia Game: navigate from  hashtag to another through Twitter posts.

We have  the Twitter API, along with Javascript and node.js to grab necessary data. The whole game is built  jQuery and socket.io.

Beca there are hundreds of thousands of Twitter posts, there has to be a way of filtering all the hashtags, so as to leave only the s that are relatively similar. Otherwise, the game is pretty much impossible to complete.
We have tried to   of the Majestic API to categorise various hashtags, but this has proved to be quite a challenge to implement, given the constraints on API calls and the limitations of the API itself.

We are satisfied with learning on how to interact with a Web service through API calls with node.js.

We have gained experience with  an API as a basis for a completely new platform, alongside with getting to know server-side scripting and HTTP to  requests.
 Twitterace
Integrate Majestic API to help pick out hashtags that are somewhat similar and realistically close in terms of Twitter posts.

Initially what we wanted to do was create some sort of "bot" to have a conversation for around 20 minutes with however this proved to take more time than we expected so we decided to  something that just translates text into another language over the ph.
However since Google Cloud Speech doesn't like the recording Tio is spitting out we had to lower to bar again.
And so at midnight we binned a lot of stuff and rewrote everything to get to the point where we are today.

Vertaler is a translator, but not just any translator. A translator you can text. A translator that'll call you back. A translator that might even text you back! That's what Vertaler is. Not just a translator but a companion.

The whole api endpoint is built in Sinatra since Flask is too over and Ruby is a nice and comfy language.
 the Twilio and Google Cloud gem we were able to translate the phrase we wanted to translate and then either call or text back  Tio.

Google Cloud Speech.

It s.

How to  the Google Cloud API.
 Vertaler
Speech to Speech support.
Source Code
require "sinatra"
require "twilio-ruby"
require "google/cloud"
require "unicode"
require "unidecoder"

accountSid = ENV['TIO_SID']
authToken  = ENV['TIO_AUTH']
apiKey     = ENV['GOOGLE_TRANSLATE']

gcloud  = Google::Cloud.new
tio = Twilio::REST::Client.new accountSid, authToken

hashLanguages = {
  'Afrikaans'           => 'af',
  'Albanian'            => 'sq',
  'Arabic'              => 'ar',
  'Armenian'            => 'hy',
  'Azerbaijani'         => 'az',
  'Basque'              => 'eu',
  'Belarusian'          => 'be',
  'Bengali'             => 'bn',
  'Bosnian'             => 'bs',
  'Bulgarian'           => 'bg',
  'Catalan'             => 'ca',
  'Cebuano'             => 'ceb',
  'Chichewa'            => 'ny',
  'Chinese Simplified'  => 'zh-CN',
  'Chinese Traditional' => 'zh-TW',
  'Croatian'            => 'hr',
  'Czech'               => 'cs',
  'Danish'              => 'da',
  'Dutch'               => 'nl',
  'English'             => 'en',
  'Esperanto'           => 'eo',
  'Estonian'            => 'et',
  'Filipino'            => 'tl',
  'Finnish'             => 'fi',
  'French'              => 'fr',
  'Galician'            => 'gl',
  'Georgian'            => 'ka',
  'German'              => 'de',
  'Greek'               => 'el',
  'Gujarati'            => 'gu',
  'Haitian Creole'      => 'ht',
  'Hausa'               => 'ha',
  'Hebrew'              => 'iw',
  'Hindi'               => 'hi',
  'Hmong'               => 'hmn',
  'Hungarian'           => 'hu',
  'Icelandic'           => 'is',
  'Igbo'                => 'ig',
  'Indsian'          => 'id',
  'Irish'               => 'ga',
  'Italian'             => 'it',
  'Japanese'            => 'ja',
  'Javanese'            => 'jw',
  'Kannada'             => 'kn',
  'Kazakh'              => 'kk',
  'Khmer'               => 'km',
  'Korean'              => 'ko',
  'Lao'                 => 'lo',
  'Latin'               => 'la',
  'Latvian'             => 'lv',
  'Lithuanian'          => 'lt',
  'Macedonian'          => 'mk',
  'Malagasy'            => 'mg',
  'Malay'               => 'ms',
  'Malayalam'           => 'ml',
  'Maltese'             => 'mt',
  'Maori'               => 'mi',
  'Marathi'             => 'mr',
  'Mongolian'           => 'mn',
  'Myanmar (Burmese)'   => 'my',
  'Nepali'              => 'ne',
  'Norwegian'           => 'no',
  'Persian'             => 'fa',
  'Polish'              => 'pl',
  'Portuguese'          => 'pt',
  'Punjabi'             => 'ma',
  'Romanian'            => 'ro',
  'Russian'             => 'ru',
  'Serbian'             => 'sr',
  'Sesotho'             => 'st',
  'Sinhala'             => 'si',
  'Slovak'              => 'sk',
  'Slovenian'           => 'sl',
  'Somali'              => 'so',
  'Spanish'             => 'es',
  'Sudanese'            => 'su',
  'Swahili'             => 'sw',
  'Swedish'             => 'sv',
  'Tajik'               => 'tg',
  'Tamil'               => 'ta',
  'Telugu'              => 'te',
  'Thai'                => 'th',
  'Turkish'             => 'tr',
  'Ukrainian'           => 'uk',
  'Urdu'                => 'ur',
  'Uzbek'               => 'uz',
  'Vietnamese'          => 'vi',
  'Welsh'               => 'cy',
  'Yiddish'             => 'yi',
  'Yoruba'              => 'yo',
  'Zulu'                => 'zu'
}

hashLocales = {
  'da' => "da-DK",
  'de' => "de-DE",
  'en' => "en-GB",
  'ca' => "ca-ES",
  'es' => "es-ES",
  'fi' => "fi-FI",
  'fr' => "fr-FR",
  'it' => "it-IT",
  'ja' => "ja-JP",
  'ko' => "ko-KR",
  'nb' => "nb-NO",
  'nl' => "nl-NL",
  'pl' => "pl-PL",
  'pt' => "pt-PT",
  'ru' => "ru-RU",
  'sv' => "sv-SE",
  'zh' => "zh-CN"
}

post '/' do
  sender      = params['From'],
  receiver    = params['To']
  body        = params['Body']
  arrBody     = /(.*) in (.*)/.match(body)
  phrase      = arrBody[1]
  language    = arrBody[2]
  country     = hashLanguages[language]
  locale      = hashLocales[country]
  translate   = gcloud.translate apiKey
  translation = translate.translate phrase, to: country
  if locale.nil?
    tio.account.messages.create({
      :from => receiver,
      :to => sender,
      :body => "The phrase '#{phrase}' in '#{language}' is '#{translation.text}'",
    })
  else
    ascii_str = translation.text.to_ascii
    puts ascii_str
    ascii_str = ascii_str.gsub! ' ', '%20'
    phrase_escaped = phrase.gsub! ' ', '%20'
    call = tio.account.calls.create(
      :url  => "http://0cdef1d3.ngrok.io/voice?Text=#{ascii_str}&Phrase=#{phrase_escaped}&Country=#{translation.to}&Locale=#{locale}&Language=#{language}",
      :to   => sender,
      :from => receiver
    )
  end
  Twilio::TwiML::Response.new do |r|
    r.Message "Welcome to Vertaler, the SMS translation service. You've just asked me to translate the phrase '#{phrase}' into '#{language}'."
  end.text
end
post '/voice' do
  translation = params['Text']
  country     = params['Country']
  locale      = params['Locale']
  phrase      = params['Phrase']
  language    = params['Language']

  Twilio::TwiML::Response.new do |r|
    r.Say "The phrase #{phrase} in #{language} is", voice: 'alice'
    r.Say translation, voice: 'alice', language: locale
    r.Say "Good bye!"
  end.text
end

project_description:
My dad had this idea. The tools we have today for searching the Bible are great, but they are largely keyword and topical search based, which s it infeasible to ask questions in natural language form about issues important to 's personal lives (i.e. culturally relevant questions), which may not appear in the Bible in direct language. We need a new search engine to enable any to ask a culturally relevant question and get a meaningful response directly from the Scripture. This would do 2 things: help Christians grow their faith and be an evangelistic tool for non-Christians who have little or no Bible knowledge. D right, with the right resources, it could be  of the best tools for understanding what the Scripture really says.

hackathon_name: Code for the Kingdom Bay Area Hackathon 2016
project_description:
Register interest in the Prayer Button!

We created a product for telling a prayer buddy that we're praying, by pressing a button.
How it 
This is an AWS IoT Button. When I press the button it connects over wifi, and tells my prayer buddy that I'm praying, via an app on their ph.

Swift v3 iOS iPh app, and the AWS Button talks to the AWS IoT service, which triggers an AWS Lambda, which talks to the Go backend hosted on Pivotal Web Services (PaaS), and  a AWS SimpleDB database.
What's next
We'd like to enable church communities to  this with prayer buddies so all they need to do is hand out pairs of devices. We want it to be possible to  this to do anonymous prayer buddies too. We have started looking into buttons that   on cellular nets and vibrate when the buddy prays. And we'd like to expand the app so you could look at your prayer history, and we'd like to add incentives to bring you break to praying when life gets on-top of you.
Why
While smartphs have increased the connection we have with each other through social apps, and made it easier for us to carry a Bible with us everywhere. They can get in the way of quality time with God.
As an example: Sometimes I'll think "Oh I should check-in with my buddy and pray for them" and I get my ph out to shoot them a message and then get distracted by an Facebook notification.
We wanted to tell our prayer buddies that we're praying, without needing to interact with our phs.
C4TK
c4tksanfrancisco
Praying icon by Cristiano Zoucas from the Noun Project

hackathon_name: Code for the Kingdom Bay Area Hackathon 2016
project_description:
WeChat platform is the most popular messages and social media platform in China. What if we could better reach the Chinese with an integrated chat bot that could help  learn more about the Bible.

Provide a simple reading plan for some who has never encountered the Bible. Answer basic questions and respond with topical information and verse lookup via the WeChat messages app.
Begin by subscribing to the Gospel Guide bot on wechat. The bot responds with a welcome and instructions. Commands such as Start, Stop, Next, allow the  to begin a new 14 day intro to the Bible reading plan. The bot  auto send you todays reading each day and keep track of what reading your are currently on. The bot  accepts voice commands  WeChat's built in voice recognition. The voice recognition currently only s for mandarin Chinese, however our app is multilingual and can accept these Chinese voice commands without issue.
 
In addition to the reading plan, s can ask basic questions such as 'What is God like?', 'Who is Jesus?', 'Who is the Holy Spirit?', and 'What is love?'. Questions that do not have automatic responses are forwarded to another WeChat  who can send a response back. This person could be a pastor or spiritual leader. The bot is  able to receive voice message responses.
 
The Gospel Guide bot can respond with Bible text lookups. Simply send a message containing a Bible verse, chapter, or range, and the bot  send you the full text. If you would like more information about a verse or passage you can send a mesage containing keywords such as 'explain', 'I don't understand', 'commentary' followed by a scripture passage and the bot  send you a link to a Bible commentary on that passage!


Multilingual English/Chinese




We built the Gospel Guide bot  Python, Flask, and Redis running on a Heroku.com server.

Overall, the coding went smoothly. The biggest issue we had was understanding the limited WeChat documentation on message passing. Beca the documentation was translated from Chinese, many questions we had were left unanswered and were solved through trial and error. Other  included bugs from  with utf-8 characters and handling the different  cases for text messages, video messages, and audio messages.

We built a  Chat bot!

I (Ben) learned Python this weekend, thanks to the help of Femi!
 WeChat Bible bot
More Chinese integration

project_description:
A python script calculates the difference at each second in the SCADA data between two pumps at the same station. The difference jumps when  pump behaves differently to usual meaning it may have failed or started to slow down.
Given more time, these observations could be included with other features to try and predict a pump failure before it actually happens.

The  came from tackling down discrimination against members of the LGBTQ community. Being discriminated against for being who you are and being denied access to bathroom and other services beca of that was something we were not too fond of. We took it upon ourselves to help out members of this wonderful community, more specifically those who are homeless and tech savvy, and created something that is so simple to  in an attempt to connect them to services that they seek.

Our app connects those without wifi-access to gender neutral restrooms and charging outlets nearby. All that the  has to do is text our ph number.

We built our services  twilio, api.ai and different apis we  from sites like refugerestrooms.org and google places. We then integrated intents within api.ai and connected them to our twilio ph number that would then bring about information from the cloud in heroku which sent back information from refugerestrooms.org and google places.
 I ran into
Training our intents was a bit difficult for there are millions of ways that an interaction can take place between our s and our bot. , connecting places nearby with s in need, and training our bot to know whether an establishment is open or not took some digging.
 that I'm proud of
We are proud to be able to to reach out and impact that lives of those in deed. Although it may not be in a large scale yet, i feel honored that i can create something that can touch and impact so many  who are in need, in a positive effective way.
What I learned
I learned that you dont have to relate to anything or any in particular to lend a helping hand. At the end of the days we are all humans, created equally and we should strive to always help those in need. There is nothing more rewarding than to be able to create something that can benefit the lives of others'.
 LooBot
We started LooBoot 2 weeks prior to demo day. With such little time on our side, we have created an MVP that touches solely on gender neutral restrooms and ph outlets nearby for those needing this service. We plan on growing and expanding our service by integrating shelters, ho accessibility, soup kitchens and much more.

When the discriminatory legislation known as North Carolina’s HB2 (“the bathroom bill”) came into national spotlight earlier this year, we were interested in learning more about it and its impact on the trans and gender-queer community, especially from  whose lives would be directly affected. Naturally, we clicked on #HB2 on Twitter, expecting to browse through personal perspectives shared online; to our disappointment, we only saw coverage by national media outlets and personal narratives were few and far between. This is due to Twitter’s algorithm prioritizing crowd traffic over individual voices and the same phenomenon is seen across the modern media landscape. This made us interested in creating a impact sharing platform designed to feature individual LGBT voices.
The more we brainstormed the idea, the more we realized the potential value these shared stories could have as a vehicle for political advocacy—so we began to investigate how we might introduce advocacy features into the app. As we aimed to improve on what’s available today, we examined the shortcomings of advocacy organizations and platforms like the Human Rights Campaign and the White Ho’s We The . We saw that we could create a more agile, strategic and purposed tool for LGBT personal advocacy.

Speakout provides consumer-facing apps that empower citizens to share their personal stories and see the personal stories of others who are impacted by LGBT legislation. Through the app, it amplifies their voices and  encourages them to contact their elected representatives. 
The server  provides API access that could provide valuable insight for NGOs interested in the perspectives of everyday LGBT  whose perspectives provide valuable research. 

Eddie designed the wireframes, built the iPh application  Swift, and built the server and API  Firebase as the backend. Leonard developed the Android app. We stayed in regular contact so we could collaborate on the broader mission and  sure our respective projects aligned. 

We ran into many technical  (implementing authentication, connecting to the backend, parsing data). 
We  ran into  deciding how to our s could present themselves on the app. For political advocacy, it is often most effective to have official names and official addresses on petitions. But for many in our community, official names may not be how we see ourselves, and sharing their addresses may impact their safety. For this reason, we have made it open-ended what  can choose to share. 

We’re proud of completing two apps, creating a server, implementing live data from the Sunlight Foundation and Google’s Civic API -- and in less than 9 weeks!

Leonard learned a lot about Android development, including implementing fragments, implementing images and interacting with servers. 
 Speakout
We would love to  directly with an LGBT rights organizations (domestic or international) interested in gaining the perspective of LGBT  on a specific issue, then  Speakout to empower that community to be heard.
